input:
5 AI projects you can build in (less than) an hour
PDF Summarization tool
Clustering customer reviews
Document QA Chatbot
YT comment sentiment analysis
Gmail inbox categorization
writing_steps:
Step 1:
- Purpose: To educate and inspire readers by providing practical AI project ideas they can build quickly, possibly validating AI education/content ideas.
- Target audience: Aspiring AI engineers, beginners, and entrepreneurs looking for quick, hands-on project inspiration.

Step 2: Wireframe
[Hook about AI project quick-starts]
[List of 5 projects with a 1-line explanation each]
[CTA: Ask for more project ideas or additions]

Step 3: Body
Share the 5 projects with short, literal explanations for each, focusing on how they're approachable fast-builds.

Step 4: CTA
What would you add to this list?

Step 5A: Hook Directions
- [User’s own phrasing] “5 AI projects you can build in (less than) an hour”
- [Problem/solution] “Most tutorials take too much time. Here are 5 you can tackle before your next meeting.”
- [Results/outcomes] “Yes, you can get real AI apps running in under 60 minutes.”
- [Beginner-to-expert clarity] “You don’t need weeks to get hands-on with AI.”
- [Trend/urgency] “AI experiments don’t have to eat up your weekend.”

Step 5B: Hook Notes
- [User’s phrasing] Direct, matches search queries and clear list intent.
- [Problem/solution] Many people are overwhelmed by project scope/time; this post gives them literal, small wins.
- [Results] Focusing on speed and practical outcome.
- [Clarity] Dispel the myth that you need tons of setup or deep experience to try these.

Step 5C: Choose strongest direction: User’s own phrasing is clearest and most literal to post intent. “5 AI projects you can build in (less than) an hour.”

Step 6: Draft Post
5 AI projects you can build in (less than) an hour

Most people think you need days (or weeks) to build something cool with AI.

But here are 5 projects you can finish in under 60 minutes — each with immediate, practical value:

1. PDF Summarization tool: Upload a document and get a concise summary in seconds using GPT or similar APIs.
2. Clustering customer reviews: Use standard libraries to group feedback by theme or sentiment for quick insights.
3. Document QA Chatbot: Turn a document into an interactive Q&A bot using existing LLM frameworks.
4. YouTube comment sentiment analysis: Analyze YT video comments; spot trends, positive/negative feedback fast.
5. Gmail inbox categorization: Sort your inbox by topic or intent with text classification, no plugins required.

What would you add to this list?

Step 7: Review for style, voice, and flow
- No motivational language.
- No figurative language or idioms.
- Clear, literal, actionable. Bullet list for scannability.
- Matches example posts (see Project List and YouTube Resource List examples).
- CTA is singular, direct, non-reflective.
- No clichés. Single em dash used for clarity ("here are 5 projects you can finish in under 60 minutes — each with immediate, practical value:"). Justified.

Step 8: Final Post
